intro.description: This cheatsheet will introduce the GNU Autotools plugin by importing an existing project that uses Autotools.

subitem.label: From the main menu, select File -> Import ... -> Projects from CVS.

If the following repository does not already exist, create it by selecting "Create a new repository location", pressing "Next", and filling in the following information: Host: sourceware.org Repository path: /cvs/eclipse User: <anonymous> Connection type: pserver
Press Next to advance to CVS module selection.
Choose "Use an existing module" and open "autotools" and select "sources" in the populated list of projects.
Press Next.
Ensure "Check out as a project configured using the New Project wizard" is selected.
Press Finish.
Select C/C++ -> C Project
Within the C Project dialog, open the GNU Autotools category in the tree view and select "Empty Project"
Give the project a name. For this example, choose "sources".
Press Next.
Press Finish.
If asked to switch to C/C++ Perspective, select ok and choose to default this behavior
Navigate to the project in the Project Explorer view by selecting the "sources" project you just created.
Open the Project pull-down from the main menu
If "Build Automatically" is not checked, select "Build Project"

item.title: View build output
item.description: In the Console view, there is a button entitled "Display Selected Console". Its icon depicts a monitor with two lines of text on it. Pressing this button will drop down to show all available consoles. At this point, you should have three consoles: one for configure output ("Configure"), one for build output ("C-Build"), and one for the binary output that you just ran ("<terminated> sources ...").

subitem.label: View configure output by selecting the Configure console in the drop-down list.
View build output by selecting the "C-Build" console in the drop-down list.
Navigate to the project in the Project Explorer view by selecting the "sources" project you just created.
Open the project by toggling the arrow to the left of the project name if it is not already open.
Expand the "Binaries" virtual folder under the project.
Select the binary itself. This will be called "a.out" if you followed the example.
Right-click on the binary itself and select "Run As" -> "Local C/C++ Application".
Select "gdb Debugger" (the default) in the "Launch Debug Configuration Selection" dialog.
Press OK.

item.title: View output
item.description: The output of the program should be displayed in the Console view which should be one of the tabs visible in the bottom of the IDE. If you made no modifications, it should read "hello world".

subitem.label: Select the project "sources" if it is not already selected in the Project Explorer.
From the main menu, select Project -> Properties.
Expand "Autotools" and select "Configure Settings".
Under "configure", select "Advanced".
In the "Additional command-line options" text box, enter "--enable-option-x".
Press OK.

item.title: Finished!
item.description: Congratulations! You now have a simple GNU autotools project.
